newsitem.title: USA: ADR REPORT - Mexican ADRs stage mild recovery.
newsitem.headline: ADR REPORT - Mexican ADRs stage mild recovery.

text.p: Mexican shares traded in the U.S. recovered some lost ground but suffered from thin U.S. volumes Wednesday as worries about U.S. interest rates kept investors sidelined.
"It's kind of a rebound after yesterday. Cetes rates came in basically in line with expectations," a trader said.
Traders expected investors to stay on the sidelines ahead of Friday's U.S. unemployment data.
"That should give the market some indications on whether the Fed is going to tighten interest rates," one said.
Telmex's American Depositary Receipts (ADRs) inched up 1/4 to 33, while Tamsa rose 1/4 to 11-1/8, and Televisa held steady at 29-3/8 in afternoon trade.
Other Latin American shares were little changed on paltry volumes, with Brazil's Telebras off 1/4 at 74-1/4, Chile's CTC up 1/4 at 97-7/8 and Telefonica de Argentina down 3/8 at 23-3/4.
BAESA was one of the region's biggest gainers, bouncing 1/2 to 5-7/8 after its recent battering.
In other activity, most foreign oil shares held their gains, although some investors did take profits after the stocks' rally Tuesday on the back of U.S. missile attacks against Iraq.
"People are still perceiving that Iraqi oil is not going to be coming back on the market for awhile," a trader said.
Elf gained 1/4 to 37-7/8, Total held steady at 37-7/8, Repsol shed 3/8 to 32-1/2, BP lost 5/8 to 118-5/8, Royal Dutch added 7/8 to 153-3/4 and YPF was unchanged at 21-5/8.
Elsewhere, Britain's Vodafone sank over seven percent, dropping 2-3/4 to 34-7/8 after NatWest's U.K. analyst downgraded the stock to hold from add.
